articles.headline: U.S. Will Allow Drilling for Oil in Arctic Ocean
articles.snippet: The move is a major victory for Shell, but environmentalists say a possible accident there could have far-reaching consequences.
articles.abstract: The move is a major victory for Shell, but environmentalists say a possible accident there could have far-reaching consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday gave conditional approval to allow Shell to start drilling for oil off the Alaskan coast this summer, a major victory for the petroleum industry and a devastating blow to environmentalists.

articles.headline: Fight Over China Currency Policies Threatens Vote on Trade Bill
articles.snippet: Democrats say they will filibuster a trade measure set for a vote Tuesday unless it is combined with a separate customs enforcement bill that would crack down on currency manipulation.
articles.abstract: Democrats say they will filibuster a trade measure set for a vote Tuesday unless it is combined with a separate customs enforcement bill that would crack down on currency manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A heated dispute over how to challenge China on currency policy has imperiled a trade bill that has become President Obama’s top legislative priority, uniting even the president’s top Democratic supporters against taking up the bill in the Senate.

articles.headline: Judge’s Ruling Against 2 Banks Finds Misconduct in ’08 Crash
articles.snippet: Judge Denise L. Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Nomura and the Royal Bank of Scotland misled Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.abstract: Judge Denise L. Cote of Federal District Court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Nomura and the Royal Bank of Scotland misled Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many on Wall Street have long argued that the banks did not generally break the law when they packaged shoddy mortgages and sold them to investors in the lead-up to the financial crisis of 2008.

articles.headline: 2 Police Lives Lost Are the Focus in Mississippi
articles.snippet: Scores of law enforcement officers and hundreds of ordinary citizens attended the memorial service for two Hattiesburg, Miss., police officers who were shot during a traffic stop Saturday.
articles.abstract: Scores of law enforcement officers and hundreds of ordinary citizens attended the memorial service for two Hattiesburg, Miss., police officers who were shot during a traffic stop Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — By the time a single bagpiper marched to the front of Hattiesburg Hall on Monday afternoon, scores of law enforcement officers from across Mississippi had lined the walls of the room in a local convention center. They, along with hundreds of ordinary citizens, had come to remember two young police officers, to seek solace and, perhaps, to seek meaning.

articles.headline: TV Networks Borrow Page From Digital Rivals to Attract Advertisers
articles.snippet: Television networks are offering new data-driven products to help advertisers reach targeted audiences even as they shift to digital and social media.
articles.abstract: Television networks are offering new data-driven products to help advertisers reach targeted audiences even as they shift to digital and social media.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola has created some of the most memorable commercials in television history. Now the company is looking for something more.

articles.headline: Main Street Portfolios Are Investing in Unicorns
articles.snippet: Investors in certain mutual funds may not realize that they have bought shares of private start-up technology companies at sky-high valuations.
articles.abstract: Investors in certain mutual funds may not realize that they have bought shares of private start-up technology companies at sky-high valuations.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Uber now reportedly valued at $50 billion, there are justifiable worries that some private start-up technology companies worth $1 billion or more — known as unicorns — are in bubble territory.

articles.headline: King’s Absence at Meeting Signals a Saudi-U.S. Marriage Adrift
articles.snippet: Both countries insisted that King Salman of Saudi Arabia was not snubbing President Obama by skipping meetings at Camp David, though it seemed to reflect a new reality that the allies are at odds.
articles.abstract: Both countries insisted that King Salman of Saudi Arabia was not snubbing President Obama by skipping meetings at Camp David, though it seemed to reflect a new reality that the allies are at odds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by King Salman of Saudi Arabia to skip a summit meeting called by President Obama reflects a new reality for two nations that for generations shared goals in the Middle East but that are now at odds in fundamental ways.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Push to End Prison Rapes Loses Earlier Momentum
articles.snippet: After decades of societal indifference, Congress unanimously passed the Prison Rape Elimination Act in 2003. But the urgency behind that consensus has dissipated.
articles.abstract: After decades of societal indifference, Congress unanimously passed the Prison Rape Elimination Act in 2003. But the urgency behind that consensus has dissipated.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BOSTON, Tex. — The inmate, dressed in prison whites with a shaved head and incongruously tender eyes behind wire-rimmed glasses, entered the visiting room with her wrists joined as if she were handcuffed. At 31, she had spent her whole adult life behind bars, and it looked like a posture of habit.

articles.headline: Verizon Bets on Video Ads in $4 Billion Deal for AOL
articles.snippet: Verizon’s $4.4 billion all-cash deal for AOL illustrates how the communications industry has changed, even if the underlying rationale has not.
articles.abstract: Verizon’s $4.4 billion all-cash deal for AOL illustrates how the communications industry has changed, even if the underlying rationale has not.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest wireless operator sees its digital future in a company that still offers dial-up Internet service.

articles.headline: AOL, a Digital Pioneer, With Another Chance to Reshape Itself
articles.snippet: Acquisitions were once a symbol of the company, but the onetime Internet titan had in recent years been dogged by rumors of deals it should pursue.
articles.abstract: Acquisitions were once a symbol of the company, but the onetime Internet titan had in recent years been dogged by rumors of deals it should pursue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after Tim Armstrong was named chief executive of AOL in 2009, he started reading the management book “You’re in Charge, Now What?”
articles.byline: By Emily Steel and Michael J. de la Merced
